executive_summary: The Flour Milling industry manufactures milled products, including various flours, rice and malt. Despite a significant shift away from wheat flour consumption, demand for products has grown as rising health consciousness has driven consumers toward gluten-free and whole-grain foods. Also, the pandemic sparked a trend in at-home baking, attracting more consumers. At the same time, the price of certain input commodities has increased in recent years, raising operational costs. Imports into the Flour Milling industry have also risen. Overall, revenue is expected to inch up at a CAGR of 0.4% to $22.2 billion over the five years to 2024, despite a 2.9% dip in 2023 alone. Profit, meanwhile, remained relatively stagnant during the same timeframe, representing an estimated 6.9% of revenue in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Gluten-Free Products Have Shifting Consumer Preferences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Shifting consumer tastes and preferences have threatened the industry's growth as per capita wheat flour consumption declined. Rising public concern regarding gluten and increased commodity prices have constrained demand for wheat flour products. While rising health consciousness hinders demand for wheat flour products, it has also encouraged consumers to purchase gluten-free products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Flour Milling Operators Have Encountered Fierce Global Competition
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising imports indicate domestic flour milling companies have been increasingly underpriced or outperformed by foreign competitors. Many foreign flour millers are located near critical commodities, providing foreign operators a competitive advantage to cater to the domestic market.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Landscape Is Changing as Flour Mills Invest in Research and Development
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Flour Milling industry is heavily dependent on the market prices of crops and grains, which have soared over the past five years. Flour mill companies can typically pass on price hikes to consumers, contributing to revenue gains and growing profit. However, these cost increases can deter customers, potentially causing a drop in overall industry demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Input Prices and Health Trends May Change Flour Mill Operators' Strategies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Less volatile raw material prices will enable flour mill operators to anticipate commodity costs and adjust their selling prices accordingly. The world price of wheat and gluten-free commodities, such as corn, is expected to change only slightly over the next five years. While the world price of wheat is expected to inch up over the next five years, the world price of corn is anticipated to inch downward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Acquisitions Will Allow Operators to Remain Competitive
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As foreign milling companies continue to inundate the domestic market with low-cost flour and rice, the industry will encounter strong price-based competition over the coming years. Many flour milling companies will examine their supply chain for growth opportunities to remain competitive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Global Trade Will Be Crucial as the Value of the US Dollar Falls
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: An expected devaluation of the US dollar compared to its key trading partners will mitigate import penetration and support exports. A declining US dollar will make imported goods more expensive, discouraging the consumption of imported products.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry participate in the following activities: milling grains and vegetables into flour; cleaning, polishing and milling rice; and producing malt from various cereal grains. Flour milling companies purchase grain inputs, including wheat, corn, barley and rice, from wholesalers or growers directly. Companies then convert these inputs into flour, gluten, cereal groats and malt and sell such products to grocery wholesalers or other food-related industries.

threats: Import penetration into the manufacturing sector

key_trends: Changing consumer preferences have strengthened demand for gluten-free products. This has hindered the wheat product segment but has benefited other product segments in the industry.
The industry is expected to encounter strong price-based competition from foreign milling companies. Flour milling companies must strengthen their supply chains and seek growth opportunities.
Flour mill operators must comply with a wide range of labeling rules. The Food and Drug Administration enforces these regulations.
Tariffs are one form of assistance received by flour mill operators. The industry is protected to an extent from foreign competitors because of tariffs placed on products.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Operators in the food wholesaling sector typically act as middlemen between food producers and retailers. Grocery wholesalers organize and distribute food products to supermarkets, restaurants and food manufacturers.

Consumers in this market segment include companies that manufacture frozen foods, including frozen waffles, frozen pizzas and frozen side dishes and manufacturers of perishable prepared foods and dehydrated baking mixes.

Customers in this market segment range from self-employed bakers to large-scale manufacturers. Most revenue from this segment comes from large-scale manufacturers since smaller operations typically source ingredients from grocery wholesalers instead of interacting directly with millers.

Products including flour, cereal grains and meal powder are essential in manufacturing cookies, crackers and dry pasta. These staple products are pivotal for creating the dough or mixture for baking these tasty goods.

Flour, cereal grains and other products are essential ingredients in many foods manufactured for pets and livestock. These ingredients provide important nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins and fibers, promoting animal growth and energy.

products_and_services.product_description: The industry offers a variety of wheat products derived from grain, including flour, meal, bran sharps and other products like groats. Some flour mills have expanded their product lines by producing flour mixes and dough in-house and most flour mills specialize in producing basic, unmixed flour.
This product segment includes the manufacturing of rice-based products, including rice meal and rice mixes and specialized services, like rice cleaning and polishing.

Corn products make up the third-largest product segment in the industry. Corn, a vastly produced agricultural commodity within the United States, is highly versatile. It can be milled into maize flour and used to make cornmeal, bran, sharps and other products for consumption.

Malt products make up the smallest product segment in the industry. Flour mill operators convert raw grains into malt, which breweries and distilleries use as input commodities for beer and whiskey production.

tier_1_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US
Corn, Wheat & Soybean Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Animal Food Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Wheat products are negatively impacted by the growing popularity of gluten-free products as health-conscious and gluten-free trends continue to swell in popularity, causing wheat flour consumption to fall.

The rice product segment benefits from the shift toward gluten-free foods as more consumers seek gluten-free options, leading to a surge in demand for rice products as a healthier and non-gluten alternative to wheat flour.
The versatility of corn makes it cost-effective, resulting in growth for the corn product segment as corn can be milled into various products and the waste can be utilized in cattle feed production.
Falling downstream demand for malt from the breweries and distilleries industries has caused the malt product segment to decline as a revenue share.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports grow as US dollar strengthens
international_trade_points.trade_description: Rising imports over the past five years have partially resulted from a stronger US dollar, making imports more affordable for US-based manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Elimination of trade barriers boosts imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Import penetration is higher due to the elimination of trade barriers through trade agreements, promoting the trade of flour, wheat and grains, especially from Canada.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports fall due to strong US dollar
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports have declined over the last five years as the strong US dollar has made domestic products more expensive for foreign consumers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Proximity of major trading partners benefits industry
international_trade_points.trade_description: The proximity of major trading partners like Canada and Mexico benefits the industry by allowing trade to flourish due to minimal transportation costs and reduced tariffs through trade agreements.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the largest concentration of flour mill operators. Arkansas has the most flour mill operators in the region. This is predominantly because of its extensive wheat production, which requires more mill operators. The Southeast is home to most rice farmers, which incentivizes flour milling companies to locate in this region because of lower transportation costs. The region is also the most populated in the United States, which results in greater downstream demand for food service contractors, restaurants and supermarkets.

With its rich agricultural resources and easy access to shipping, the Great Lakes region has always been a sought-after location for flour milling establishments. Because of its fertile landscape and rich history in grain production, Minnesota alone holds the highest count of flour mill establishments in the entire region.

The Plains region, predominantly known for its massive wheat production, is also where flour mill operators are concentrated, enhancing the region's significant role in the food production industry. The concentration within this region reflects the importance of proximity to wheat farmers, which allows operators to access input commodities and negotiate favorable supply-side contracts.

regulations_points.regulation_description: One of the FDA's primary responsibilities is to enforce the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA). Under the FFDCA, most food manufacturers are required to comply with a wide range of labeling rules.

The EPA is a federal agency responsible for addressing environmental issues and enforcing environmental protection laws. These laws include the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act, the Pollution Prevention Act and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.
State and local governments regulate flour, rice and malt manufacturers. Government bodies are typically responsible for overseeing food safety within their jurisdictions.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry uses a substantial amount of capital during production. Heavy machinery like traditional mills or stone grinders are required. This equipment is technical and can be expensive.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators compete primarily on price. Price is directly related to a good's perceived quality, resulting in price being a critical competitive factor.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Large flour milling companies continue to acquire smaller companies or form joint ventures to improve their competitive positioning, expand their regional distribution networks and boost market share.
Combining technology, marketing and consumer insight synergies will enable flour milling companies to develop competitive advantages to help grow market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases represent the industry's most significant expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The industry primarily incurs costs from purchasing raw input commodities, including wheat, rice and other cereal grains. These purchases constitute a substantial revenue share, mainly because of volatile harvest yields translating to significant fluctuations in raw material prices.
The industry must comply with government regulations and negotiate contracts with downstream markets

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry uses a substantial amount of capital during production
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Heavy machinery like traditional mills or stone grinders are required. This equipment is technical and can be expensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served my incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in the price of critical inputs drive volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility is typically caused by fluctuations in the prices of critical inputs, like wheat and coarse grains and demand for flour, rice and malt products from downstream markets, including grocery stores and supermarkets.

Downstream demand for flour milling companies derives from consumer demand for flour and various flour-based products. These include bread, pastries like cakes and cookies, tortillas, pasta and traditional cereals.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Wheat is negatively impacted by the growing popularity of gluten-free products
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Per capita wheat flour consumption fell over the last five years, causing this segment's share of revenue to fall. As health-conscious and gluten-free trends continue to swell in popularity, wheat flour consumption will continue to be negatively impacted.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The rice product segment benefits from the shift toward gluten-free foods
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As more consumers seek gluten-free options, the growing preference for rice products as a healthier and non-gluten alternative to wheat or meslin flour will see a surge in demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The versatility of corn makes it cost effective, resulting in this segment's growth
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Corn, a vastly produced agricultural commodity within the United States, is highly versatile. It can be milled into maize flour and used to make cornmeal, bran, sharps and other products for consumption.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Falling downstream demand for malt has caused the product segment to decline
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Malt products make up the smallest product segment in the industry. Flour mill operators convert raw grains into malt, which breweries and distilleries use as input commodities for beer and whiskey production.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Imported goods satisfy a significant share of domestic demand for milled flour and malt, limiting growth opportunities for US companies. Many of these imported goods come from low-wage countries, such as Thailand, India and Mexico.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: While companies export significant volumes of milled products to foreign consumers, the value of the US dollar can significantly impact export volumes. When the value of the US dollar rises, exports are typically constricted, as domestic goods become relatively more expensive in overseas markets.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The world price of wheat can exhibit high volatility. Decreases in key commodity prices limit the prices milling companies are able to charge for their final products.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the world price of wheat has made it harder for flour milling companies to anticipate costs, therefore limiting investment into capital or purchases. In turn, profit for many of these companies has benefited from passing costs on to consumers.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Many flour milling companies enter into long-term, predetermined purchase agreements with suppliers and downstream consumers to ensure a steady revenue stream despite volatile weather and market conditions.

FAQs.question: What kinds of products do you sell? Do your products appeal to a wide variety of consumers?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators effectively market differentiated products, such as wheat flour, corn flour and various mixed flours, to cater to a variety of consumer preferences and, therefore, capture maximum market share. Having a range of products by premiumization can help producers shift with changing consumer preferences based on economic conditions.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to automate any of your milling processes? What have been the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators increasingly depend on machinery and equipment to automate processes, which reduces the need for labor and lowers wage costs.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to secure input contracts? Have you been able to pass on costs when input prices are volatile?
FAQs.answer: Many operators pass on increasing input costs to downstream consumers to maintain profit. Millers can also seek fixed-price contracts.

FAQs.question: How have wheat prices affected your profitability? Are you able to pass on commodity costs to your customers?
FAQs.answer: As individuals consume more significant quantities of bread, pasta, frozen meals and other wheat flour-derived foods, demand for flour milling services increases. When the world price of wheat rises, most millers will pass costs along to downstream markets, but stiff competition means millers must be strategic with pricing.

FAQs.question: How does a rise in per capita disposable income affect your bottom line? Do you produce value-added goods for when incomes are high?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income measures the average individual's ability to purchase goods or services. As disposable income rises, consumers can purchase more goods derived from industry services and trade up to premium products, boosting industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How are you affected by rising imports? How can you combat this trend?
FAQs.answer: Increasing demand for imports within the manufacturing sector is reflected by falling demand for goods manufactured within the United States. Promoting the premium quality of goods can help offset rising competition from imported brands and forming strong consumer bonds.
